text.section:
A community action agency shall plan systematically for an effective community action program, and in doing so shall:
evaluate information on the causes and problems of poverty in the community;
assess the use and impact of current financial assistance; and
establish priorities among projects, activities, and target areas to achieve the best and most efficient use of resources.

A community action agency shall:
encourage subsidiary boards, councils, and agencies engaged in projects related to a community action program to plan for, secure, and administer available financial assistance on a cooperative basis; and
provide technical and organizational assistance to the subsidiary boards, councils, and agencies.

A community action agency shall initiate and sponsor community projects to help meet the needs of low-income persons with particular emphasis on:
establishing a pool of resources to serve a variety of community action programs;
developing versatile approaches and services; and
implementing stopgap measures pending the expansion or modification of community action programs.

A community action agency shall:
establish procedures for community residents to:
influence the character of their community action programs; and
participate regularly in implementing those programs; and
provide the necessary technical and advisory support to enable low-income persons and community groups to secure public and private financial assistance for themselves.

A community action agency shall join with and encourage business, labor, and other private or public officials and organizations to support community action programs that:
use private resources and capabilities for new employment opportunities;
stimulate investments that measurably reduce poverty in areas of concentrated poverty; and
provide residents in those areas with methods to work with private organizations, firms, and institutions to seek solutions to problems of common concern.
